title: Walmart Stock’s Continuing Gain Could Be Linked to Procter & Gamble
text:
Text size

Procter & Gamble topped earnings expectations and raised its 2020 guidance. That could be great news for Walmart.

Walmart (ticker: WMT) doesn’t report earnings until Nov. 14, more than two weeks from now. The company is expected to report a profit of $1.09 a share on sales of $128.5 billion, and it better surpass those numbers if it knows what’s good for it: Its stock has gained 6.1% during the past three months and 28% in 2019. That’s a lot of good news already reflected in its $119.10 price.

We’re feeling pretty confident that Walmart can do what it needs to do.

As Walmart has ratcheted up its online business, it has also gotten better at using all of its assets to make it work, writes Gordon Haskett Research Advisors analyst Chuck Grom. He points to Walmart’s grocery pickup and delivery, its health clinics, and its other initiatives to help draw new customers in while giving existing ones even more reasons to shop there. “In the near term, this is unequivocally helping comps, and when we think ahead over the next five to 10 years, Walmart’s focus on building out that ecosystem could pay dividends for many years to come,” Grom explains.

Still, we’re more concerned about what happens in a couple of weeks, and that is where Procter & Gamble (PG) comes in. P&G reported its results this past week, and they were lights out. Earnings per share came in at $1.37, on sales of $17.8 billion, easily topping forecasts for $1.25 and $17.4 billion, respectively. Better yet, P&G raised the top end of its 2020 organic-growth range and lifted its earnings guidance. P&G stock gained a well-deserved 4.9% for the week.

Newsletter Sign-up

What does any of this have to do with Walmart? After all, it’s a retailer, while Procter & Gamble manufactures consumer goods. Those businesses aren’t as distinct as they might seem. Walmart sells P&G products—lots of them. In fact, it accounts for some 15% of P&G’s sales, notes Morgan Stanley analyst Simeon Gutman, so if P&G is doing well, there’s a good chance that Walmart is, too. Furthermore, Gutman says, the correlation between Walmart’s “comps” and Procter’s organic-volume growth on a trailing-five-year basis has climbed above 70%, from negative 20% in 2016.

Gutman acknowledges that P&G isn’t a perfect read-through for Walmart. Walmart, for instance, sells groceries, which Procter doesn’t make, while P&G’s international sales make up 60% of total revenue, compared with just 25% for Walmart.

Still, the two companies have something else in common that makes Walmart a good bet: their size. “Since around 2015, both companies’ top-line trajectories have trended in a similar direction,” Gutman writes. “We believe the convergence in growth trends we are witnessing, with P&G and Walmart both displaying stronger top-line growth, reaffirms the view that large companies are better leveraging scale to gain share across the consumer landscape.”

And it may be doing so just when Amazon, every retailer’s biggest boogeyman, no longer looks so invincible. Amazon’s shares dropped 1% on Friday after it missed earnings expectations, as operating margins fell to 3% from 4% due, in part, to higher shipping costs. Yet even before its earnings miss, Amazon looked as if it was playing catch-up. Its stock price has dropped 3.5% during the past 12 months, even as Walmart has gained 20% and Target (TGT) has climbed 31%.

We won’t know for two weeks, but don’t be surprised if the good times continue for Walmart.

Write to Ben Levisohn at Ben.Levisohn@barrons.com
description: Walmart stock has gained 28% in 2019, and the retailer’s initiatives can attract new customers and give existing ones more reasons to shop there. Investors could look to Procter & Gamble to see where shares are headed.
